)Comparison of ContextNet and Random Forest Classifiers ContextNet Random Forest Classifiers Placeholder Figure 8: Average Precision and Mean Average Precision: ContextNet Versus Random 
Forests The graph shows Average Precision (AP) scores for both ContextNet and Random Forests in the indivual 
contexts of the LBM Dataset, along with Alert. The mean Average Precision (mAP) is also displayed on the far 
right. We found that there was a wide range of difficulty for the various contexts, with boating being 
one of the easiest to detect, and destructive being one of the hardest to detect. The hardest 
contexts to detect were typically ones with a very limited number of positive examples in the 
training set, and we believe performance in these categories would be significantly improved by 
obtaining additional training examples. Of the 22 labels (including Alert), ContextNet achieved a 
higher AP score in 13 labels with a 3% higher overall mAP score than Random Forests. 
ContextNet and Random Forests were approximately tied in 5 labels and Random Forests 
performed better in only 4 labels. In these 4 labels, Random Forests had significantly higher AP 
scores than ContextNet, the most notable of which was a rare context benign boating. One 
possible explanation for this result is the simpler way that decision trees handle features. Decision xv trees always split along a feature dimension, thus, if there are a few simple but effective scene 
features that can instantly distinguish a context (rather than a more complex interaction among 
features), then the forests may do a better job than ContextNet in selecting these features and 
ignoring noise from irrelevant features. This is especially likely for contexts with few positive 
examples. For example, the Video Entity Detection module can detect boats, cars, buses and other 
vehicles, which could be instantly useful to identify benign boating or traffic-vehicular. 
Additionally, there are audio entities for screaming that would be directly useful to identifying the 
screaming context. These features are available for ContextNet to use too; however, with few 
positive training examples, it is harder to train ContextNet because it is a more complex model 
than Random Forests. The results also suggest that ContextNet is better at detecting more complex 
and nuanced contexts, such as injury, destructive and most importantly Alert. These are 
more abstract concepts that require more complex fusion from multiple domains to detect. 
ContextNet is capable of combining features in this way, while Random Forests is limited to 
splitting along one feature at a time. Alert: ContextNet on the LBM Dataset5.2
In this section, we give special attention to the performance of the Alert of ContextNet. 
Mechanically speaking, the Alert label is handled identically to any other context, but for the 
LinkBioMan system as a whole, it has a special importance because of the systems overall aim 
at generating near-real-time alerts for complex real-world situations. Alert is also unique because it 
is extremely open-ended in its definition. The other context labels generated by ContextNet 
represent fairly concrete concepts such as airport, crowd, screaming or fighting. Such 
labels can have a broad range of characteristics, but they are all still much more specific than 
Alert which could represent many different scenarios, such as, riots, injuries, fires, car accidents, 
robberies, floods, and more. For this reason, ContextNets understanding of alert-ability is highly 
dependent on the data on which it is trained and on the annotations provided by human annotators. When trained with all possible input modules, ContextNet achieved 81.5% accuracy at detecting 
alert-able situations. However, because the LBM Dataset has a highly unbalanced number of 
positive and negative examples for most labels, accuracy is not a good metric for measuring 
performance. Instead, the preferred metric is AP, for which ContextNet achieved a score of 0.567. 
For perspective, the expected AP of a fully random system on a large data pool can be 
approximated as the ratio of true positive examples to total documents [66]. In this case, the testing 
segment of our LBM Dataset had 214 clips annotated as alert-able out of the 1094 clips total, 
giving an expected AP of only 0.196. Thus, the performance of ContextNet in detecting alert-able 
situations far exceeds random chance. We can also examine the true positive rate (TPR) and false 
positive rate (FPR) for Alerts when using a fixed threshold to convert alert probability scores into a 
binary decision. In this case we will use the simple threshold of 0.5. At this threshold, ContextNet 
has a 0.678 TPR and a 0.151 FPR. While these results are far from ideal, they are promising given 
the domain complexity, the open-endedness of what the system is expected to detect, and the 
many challenging factors included in the LBM Dataset, such as, poor image quality, wide 
variability in viewing angles, moving cameras, and missing sound. xvi Context Classifier: ContextNet, Random Forests on the TRECVid 5.3
Evaluation Dataset NIST made available the numerical scores for the TRECVid 2015 SI Task, which we used to 
compare with our context classifier performance of both ContextNet and Random Forests. These 
tests are performed on seven topics described in Section 3.3. Note that for TRECVid 2015, NIST 
used inferred Average Precision (infAP) [67] to estimate precision from their rank-ordered search 
and retrieval results based on random sampling theory. This infAP metric gives results that closely 
approximate standard AP, and thus, it should provide a fair comparison with our results, which are 
measured in AP. Table 3 presents the infAP scores and mAP score for the best performing 
TRECVid team, alongside the AP and mAP scores for ContextNet and Random Forests. Figure 9 
presents the scores of all TRECVid teams as well as those of ContextNet and Random Forests on 
the seven topics. Both approaches (ContextNet and Random Forests) outperform many of the 
TRECVid performing teams scores. Table 3: Comparison of ContextNet (CN), Random Forests (RF) 
and Best TRECVid Team on the TRECVid Evaluation Dataset The table compares the AP of ContextNet and Random Forests when applied to seven of the NIST-annotated 
topics on the TRECVid 2015 dataset. The mAP scores across all 7 topics are displayed in the bottom row of the 
table. The three colored columns indicate three different testing configurations, which are elaborated in more 
detail in the paragraphs below the table. The scores of Best TRECVid Team are reported as Inferred Average 
Precision (infAP), which approximates AP. Average Precision (AP) All Data
All Data (No Audio Used) 
Clips with Audio TRECVid Topic Best 
TRECVid Team CN CN RF CN RF Boat Ship 0.569 0.626 0.608 0.529 0.684 0.604 Cheering 0.229 0.205 0.235 0.097 0.245 0.409 Dancing 0.072 0.175 0.168 0.166 0.234 0.170 Demonstration or Protest 0.397 0.513 0.435 0.423 0.618 0.237 Explosion Fire 0.135 0.308 0.315 0.272 0.379 0.261 Running 0.280 0.241 0.185 0.299 0.259 0.400 Throwing 0.226 0.204 0.235 0.096 0.235 0.100 mAP 0.273 0.325 0.312 0.269 0.379 0.312 We performed experiments in three distinct configurations, which are highlighted in different xvii colors in Table 3. In the first configuration, All Data, we used all the clips minus the few that 
could not be processed due to technical issues (see Section 3.3 for details). For this configuration, 
we compared only ContextNets results to the best TRECVid performing teams results because, 
unlike the experiments comparing ContextNet and Random Forests using the LBM Dataset, 
we did not attempt to accommodate data of varying feature vector length for the random 
forest implementation (i.e., training and testing ContextNet and Random Forests with the 
same clips of missing audio and with audio). In three of the seven topics tested, we achieved 
higher individual topic AP scores than any other TRECVid performing teams (see Figure 9), and 
we achieved a 0.325 mAP score, far surpassing the best TRECVid performing teams score of 
0.273. These results are very promising, but they lead to two questions which we addressed with 
the other two configurations: First, considering that audio is missing in many clips, will 
ContextNet perform better if the audio features are just completely removed? Second, if we restrict 
the dataset down to only the clips with audio, will that make the problem easier and will 
ContextNet and Random Forests have better performance? Note that because many clips lack audio, we used zero-padding to replace the missing inputs to 
ContextNet. This partially missing data could have adverse effects on ContextNet and even lead to 
worse performance than if audio was completely ignored. The second configuration, All Data 
(No Audio Used), was used to answer the first question posed above. In All Data (No Audio 
Used), we used all the clips, but simply ignored all
